children.content: or "Dependencies, Trust, and the Social Contract"
I work for KA, it's awesome.
and the other thing is that libraries don't consistently indicate when a version contains breaking changes.
and it's this second point that initially got me started thinking & writing about this topic.
and there are two parts to this -- one, there are too many breaking changes, that don't have to be breaking
there are too many breaking changes
it's too hard to know if a change is breaking
because changes too often break us
And I'm going to start out with a couple of stories.

Story one: we've got an iOS app written partially in swift, and last november we updated the version of Xcode we were using. When I started it up, it said "we need to update some things", and promptly broke the build by upgrading swift from 4.0.1 to 4.0.2. It had some renamed functions, some types changed, etc. Not what I would call a "patch" release.

Story two: our Android app has one of those "facebook login" buttons, for which we use the facebook-android-sdk. Last october, we get an email from facebook saying "You're using a version of the android sdk that will soon be deprecated -- you have to upgrade or your things might break". So, I look at the releases -- we're at 4.0.0, and the latest is 4.27 -- that's a lot! I try changing the dependency to 4.27, and I get a compilation error. Ok, so these apparently aren't "minor semver changes", so all bets are off -- let's start at 4.0.0 & increment one by one to see how far we can get & still compile. I get as far as 4.10.1 (increment, compile, ok it works, increment again), and then at 4.11 it breaks. ðŸ¤·â€â™€ï¸ Well, 4.10.1 will be supported for another while, and I don't have time to figure out what all they changed that broke compilation, so we'll settle for that. I run the app, make sure the facebook login button still works, and we're all set.

Story three: I come across a bug in apollo. Start looking into things, seeing if other people have had this problem -- aha, looks like they do! And it was fixed! Oh, but it was only fixed in the new major version that they released, which has breaking changes. I look into it, and it's not two difficult an upgrade, and the bug is fixed. Hooray!

and the big question: "update all to latest?"
--- and then come back to this image when I talk about "what are ways a library can break you"
!a and what should version numbers communicate?
{2} "What is the contract between library author & consumer?"
major: will require 100s of person-hours to upgrade
bonus: deprecate things via `console.warn` for several minor versions, and then remove them in a major version.
0.X.0 releases every month, probably breaking, yolo
often includes codemods for breaking changes to ease the upgrade process

But I have two problems with semver. One is -- it's not enforced. Two, as a consumer, I super don't care! The only time I care about two version numbers is when I'm considering whether it's safe to upgrade. Will this next version break me, or will it not?
You're probably thinking "We have a solution to this --- semver! If people would only follow it, everything would be fine!!!
"What is the contract between library author & consumer?"
!a The only time I care about version numbers is when I'm upgrading.

it totally makes sense how it came about. The library author makes the version numbers, and when I'm thinking about releasing a new version, I draw a distinction between "just bugfixes" and "I added features".
some external requirement (3rd-party API deprecation, etc.)
this new version has something I want
where FOMO is really "fear of getting so far behind that upgrading will be super painful"
{3} Will this next version break me?
{3} Will this next version break me?
Redefining versioning to be more consumer-centric won't do any good if there's nothing in place to enforce it.
!a untested behavior changes (caught by users ðŸ¤·â€â™€ï¸)
maybe the order of this is wrong...

this is the tack that opam takes -- you submit a pull request asking to be admitted, they take a look at your project, and allow it if it looks good. This relies rather a lot on individual intervention, and is quite a barrier to new folks publishing.
{3} Option B: manual curation (a la opam)
if you remove or change a type or value, it's major
if you just add a type or value, it's minor
if there are no observable type changes, it's patch
this will catch the first kind of breaking changes! Awesome.
Unfortunately, types aren't the whole package -- behavior can break you as well.
and I asked twitter, and people are super pleased with it.
behavior changes -> enforce tests on publish
behavior changes -> enforce tests on publish
untested behavior changes -> run downstream tests?
So an alternative would be to just point out that if you're depending on some functionality of library x that isn't tested, you should add a test for it!
This could be quite resource intensive -- if you had, for example, the tests running on travis-ci or some docker fleet somewhere, and your library had a ton of dependents, that could get messy quick.
behavior changes -> enforce tests on publish
untested behavior changes -> encourage adding tests ðŸ˜
behavior changes -> enforce tests on publish
untested behavior changes -> encourage adding tests ðŸ˜
behavior changes -> enforce tests on publish
untested behavior changes -> encourage adding tests ðŸ˜
allowed to have multiple versions in a dep tree
your public api must not reference types from private deps
would be nice to be able to mark a package as "private", meaning that your public API doesn't use any types from that package, e.g. your usage of it is entirely internal
!a alternative: incentivise adding more tests to the first library
Idea 2: test downstream libs w/ changes

my public API has a function that returns a type from reason-react, for example. If I update my package to depend on a newer version of reason-react that modified that type I'm using, then that should be a breaking change to my library.
So, we could say "if I bump a dependency a non-patch version, then that's a breaking change"
Although, there are situations where a library uses a dependency interally only, and none of the public API uses types from that dep. It would be nice to be able to upgrade
in response to this, I propose two things
!a if it has new behavior / type, it should have a new name -- and keep the old value / type around.
!a if you're changing lots of things, just rename the library. e.g. `react_2015`
This sounds rosy, and there is a lot of value to pursuing this as much as possible -- I recommend you watch this talk, it's great.
First problem is -- maybe to complicated to describe? If you have transitive dependencies that want
There are some problems with this, however -- and we need a real way to deal with change, not just pretending it doesn't have to exist.
Another example: if you're renaming an attribute of a type, you can't just keep the old attribute around.
ohhhhh also talk about unisonweb?? could be interesting

Rich Hickey, of Clojure fame, gave a keynote two years ago, talking about similar issues, and he dug more into the nuts and bots of what kinds of changes are breaking and which are not. And his recommendation was essentially "never do breaking changes."
Case study: React w/o breaking changes
"Switch from using id attribute to data-reactid to track DOM nodes."
"`this.setState` now takes an optional callback as it's second parameter"

```
this.setState: ('stateT) => unit
/* change to */
this.setState: (~callback=?, 'stateT) => unit
```
!a Include a codemod for the rename
"`React.renderComponentToString` is now synchronous and returns the generated HTML string"

```
renderComponentToString: (reactElement, string => unit) => unit
/* became */
renderComponentToString: reactElement => string
```
!a could keep the old one around under the name `renderComponentToStringAsync`, and codemod the rename
"The lifecycle methods componentDidMount and componentDidUpdate no longer receive the root node as a parameter; use `this.getDOMNode()` instead" {"font-size": "2rem"}

```
componentDidMount: (Dom.element, self) => unit
/* became */
componentDidMount: (self) => unit
```

!a ```
componentDidMount: (node, self) => { ...
/* codemod to */
componentDidMount: (self) => { let node = getDOMNode(self); ...
```
"`MyComponent()` now returns a descriptor, not an instance"
we made it through the first year of React's changelog before we had a really breaking change!
!a codemods can dramatically reduce the number of breaking changes
Case study: React w/o breaking changes
I would love to have a community norm that makes an effort to avoid breaking changes.
seriously? You couldn't have kept the old name around with a deprecation warning?
codemods can help with the "keep around old versions" & avoid naming explosion. The current version gets the nice name, and old versions get renamed to indicate deprecation.
{3} Codemods can help dramatically reduce the number of breaking changes
make codemods much easier to do
Strategies for making change less scary
I'm excited about incentivizing community members to add tests
